dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: So, uh, diving into the airline industry, it's pretty wild right now. We're talking over a third of the global fleet of 8,500 passenger planes just... parked. Like, sitting there.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: So, uh, diving into the airline industry, it's pretty wild right now. We're talking over a third of the global fleet of eight thousand, five hundred passenger planes just... parked. Like, sitting there.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Over a third of the global fleet of 8,500 passenger planes have been parked, and scheduled flights this week will offer fewer than half as many total seats as in mid-January.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, it's pretty jarring, isn't it? And scheduled flights, I heard, are offering less than half the seats compared to back in January. But, initially, there was this idea that, um, when things ended, recovery would be quick.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, it's pretty jarring, isn't it? And scheduled flights, I heard, are offering less than half the seats compared to back in January. But, initially, there was this idea that, um, when things ended, recovery would be quick.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Over a third of the global fleet of 8,500 passenger planes have been parked, and scheduled flights this week will offer fewer than half as many total seats as in mid-January.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Right? Less than a year to return to former size, some were saying. Which, you know, sounds like good news for airplane makers. In fact, Robert Stallard, an analyst, is predicting airlines will need like, 6,300 new aircraft over the next five years. That's *more* than he thought a few months ago!
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Right? Less than a year to return to former size, some were saying. Which, you know, sounds like good news for airplane makers. In fact, Robert Stallard, an analyst, is predicting airlines will need like, six thousand, three hundred new aircraft over the next five years. That's more than he thought a few months ago!
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Airlines will need 6,300 new aircraft over the next five years, estimates Robert Stallard, an analyst with Vertical Research Partners, about 2,000 fewer than hed forecast just a few months ago.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: [interrupts] Hold on though, because that's based on some really optimistic numbers, like a 40% jump in passenger miles this year, and traffic getting back to 2018 levels by... 2026, which still feels a long way off. And Helane Becker, another analyst, thinks it'll be more like 18 to 24 months just to get to *some* level of normal.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Hold on though, because that's based on some really optimistic numbers, like a forty percent jump in passenger miles this year, and traffic getting back to twenty eighteen levels by... twenty twenty six, which still feels a long way off. And Helane Becker, another analyst, thinks it'll be more like eighteen to twenty four months just to get to some level of normal.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Thats based on an estimate of a stomach-churning 40% reduction in airline passenger miles this year, roughly matching the industry group IATAs forecast, and a slow recovery that only sees airline traffic return to 2018 levels in 2026.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Exactly. She even points out that after 9/11, it took roughly seven years for U.S. airline traffic to fully recover on certain routes. So, this "quick bounce back" might be a bit of wishful thinking.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Exactly. She even points out that after nine over eleven, it took roughly seven years for U S airline traffic to fully recover on certain routes. So, this quick bounce back might be a bit of wishful thinking.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: After 9/11, it took roughly seven years for U.S. airlines traffic to fully recover on flights over 500 miles and over 1,000 miles, she notes.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Uh, yeah. But it also means older planes are likely staying in service, permanently, especially narrowbodies. And new plane deliveries are actually being *accelerated* in some cases as airlines try to cut costs.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Uh, yeah. But it also means older planes are likely staying in service, permanently, especially narrowbodies. And new plane deliveries are actually being accelerated in some cases as airlines try to cut costs.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: With thousands of older planes likely to be retired permanently, with a tilt toward widebodies, and delivery of new planes deferred or canceled as airlines seek to cut costs, Stallard believes the active airline fleet wont return to 2019 levels until about 2025.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, Stallard actually expects Airbus and Boeing deliveries to be higher than his previous forecasts for the next few years. Like, up 21% for Airbus, 26% for Boeing. Which sounds good on paper...
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, Stallard actually expects Airbus and Boeing deliveries to be higher than his previous forecasts for the next few years. Like, up twenty one percent for Airbus, twenty six percent for Boeing. Which sounds good on paper...
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: He expects Airbus deliveries will come in 21% lower than hed previously forecast from 2020 through 2024, off 1,012 planes, while Boeing's will be down 26%, or 931 planes.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: [interrupts] But then you have Richard Aboulafia from Teal Group, who says these estimates are probably *too* optimistic. He's got, uh, a "creeping confidence" that things *could* be better, but he's cautious.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: But then you have Richard Aboulafia from Teal Group, who says these estimates are probably too optimistic. He's got, uh, a creeping confidence that things could be better, but he's cautious.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: This and other estimates may be too conservative, says Richard Aboulafia, Teal Groups vice president of analysis... I think a lot of us have a creeping anxiety it could be a whole lot worse, he says.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: For sure. He's looking at the big uncertainties: how long this pandemic lasts, how travelers will react, and how effective government support really is. There are just so many variables.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: For sure. He's looking at the big uncertainties: how long this pandemic lasts, how travelers will react, and how effective government support really is. There are just so many variables.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: This and other estimates may be too conservative, says Richard Aboulafia, Teal Groups vice president of analysis, given the many unknowns as to the length of the pandemic, how travelers will respond and the effectiveness of government efforts to support airlines, manufactures and the global economy.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: And it could be pretty catastrophic for Airbus and Boeing over the next few years. Partly because their narrowbody output was already higher than planned â€“ Airbus had production issues, Boeing with the 737 MAX grounding.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: And it could be pretty catastrophic for Airbus and Boeing over the next few years. Partly because their narrowbody output was already higher than planned - Airbus had production issues, Boeing with the seven hundred thirty seven meters A X grounding.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: However, the next few years will be somewhat less catastrophic for Airbus and Boeing than it could have been for two reasons. The plane makers narrowbody output has been lower than planned, in Airbus case due to production problems, in Boeings, because of the grounding of the troubled 737 MAX.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Right, so they've got this backlog, and now demand has just, like, cratered. And then you have governments potentially withholding financial support that could keep factories open.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Right, so they've got this backlog, and now demand has just, like, cratered. And then you have governments potentially withholding financial support that could keep factories open.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The U.S. and European governments are also lining up to provide financial support that will keep factories open and producing planes that the market doesnt really want right now.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: It's a real pickle. Boeing's actually asking for $60 billion in support. And their CEO, David Calhoun, said he'd take federal assistance even if it means giving up equity. There's also the stimulus package requiring loan recipients to keep 90% of current headcount.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: It's a real pickle. Boeing's actually asking for sixty billion dollars in support. And their C E O, David Calhoun, said he'd take federal assistance even if it means giving up equity. There's also the stimulus package requiring loan recipients to keep ninety percent of current headcount.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Boeing CEO David Calhoun said last week that he wouldnt take federal assistance if it required surrendering equity to the government.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: It's like Aboulafia said, you're 'pulling demand forward' to a certain extent with that support, which probably beats, you know, falling off a cliff entirely.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: It's like Aboulafia said, you're pulling demand forward to a certain extent with that support, which probably beats, you know, falling off a cliff entirely.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Youre pulling demand forward to a certain extent, but it probably beats falling off a cliff, says Aboulafia.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, it's a tightrope walk. They need to find a way to maintain headcount, keep some production, but also acknowledge that short-term market needs are basically approaching zero. It's a huge challenge.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, it's a tightrope walk. They need to find a way to maintain headcount, keep some production, but also acknowledge that short-term market needs are basically approaching zero. It's a huge challenge.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Both sides need to find a way production can be cut, employee head count can be cut, but some sort of support can be found for keeping production higher than actual short-term market needs, which are approaching zero, says Aboulafia.
